user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_mount:
```c
int lfs_mount(lfs_t *lfs, const struct lfs_config *cfg) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_mount(%p, %p {.context=%p, "
                ".read=%p, .prog=%p, .erase=%p, .sync=%p, "
                ".read_size=%"PRIu32", .prog_size=%"PRIu32", "
                ".block_size=%"PRIu32", .block_count=%"PRIu32", "
                ".block_cycles=%"PRId32", .cache_size=%"PRIu32", "
                ".lookahead_size=%"PRIu32", .read_buffer=%p, "
                ".prog_buffer=%p, .lookahead_buffer=%p, "
                ".name_max=%"PRIu32", .file_max=%"PRIu32", "
                ".attr_max=%"PRIu32"})",
            (void*)lfs, (void*)cfg, cfg->context,
            (void*)(uintptr_t)cfg->read, (void*)(uintptr_t)cfg->prog,
            (void*)(uintptr_t)cfg->erase, (void*)(uintptr_t)cfg->sync,
            cfg->read_size, cfg->prog_size, cfg->block_size, cfg->block_count,
            cfg->block_cycles, cfg->cache_size, cfg->lookahead_size,
            cfg->read_buffer, cfg->prog_buffer, cfg->lookahead_buffer,
            cfg->name_max, cfg->file_max, cfg->attr_max);

    err = lfs_mount_(lfs, cfg);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_mount -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
(void*)(uintptr_t)cfg->erase, (void*)(uintptr_t)cfg->sync,
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation of Rule 8.13. In the fragment cfg is a pointer to a const struct, so cfg->erase (and cfg->sync) are accessed through a const-qualified object. The (uintptr_t) and then (void*) casts are transient conversions used only for printing and do not introduce a persistent pointer variable that ought to be const. (Note: the cast sequence does discard const-qualification and converts a function pointer to an object pointer via an integer — that may violate other MISRA rules concerning pointer/integer and function-to-object-pointer conversions, but it does not itself breach Rule 8.13.)
